title: Mum helped disabled man through door then stole his wallet
text:
Lex Smith offered to help a disabled man get his wheelchair through some doors before stealing his wallet moments later (Picture: MEN Media)

A thief who stole a wallet off a disabled man she was pretending to help has been spared jail.

Mum-of-one Lex Smith offered to help her victim, who had cerebral palsy, get his wheelchair through the door of Patricroft Conservative Club in Eccles, Manchester, before running off with his possessions.

As she assisted him on August 31 this year, she grabbed his bag from around his neck, stealing his wallet and a packet of cigarettes from inside it.

A court heard here was a struggle between the two parties that lasted a ‘few seconds’ before Smith managed to run off, leaving the victim, 51, ‘shaken and appalled’.

In a victim impact statement read to Manchester Crown Court, he said ‘nothing like this’ had ever happened to him before and he believed she was genuinely trying to help.

He said: ‘I am shocked and appalled by the cheek and lack of respect this woman showed.

‘I thought she wanted to help me but at the time she just wanted to rob me.’

Smith’s victim was struggling to get through the entrance of the Patricroft Conservative Club in Eccles, Greater Manchester (Picture: Google Maps)

Manchester Crown Court heard Smith, who has 10 previous convictions for 26 offences, accepted that this was a ‘serious offence’.

She said she initially planned to help the ‘vulnerable’ man but decided to commit the offence in the ‘spur of the moment’.

Defending, David James told the court that Smith had not had a conviction for 15 years.

He said: ‘She has a 13-year-old son who has autism who needs specialist care. He is no longer living with her.

‘She has struggled with drug addiction throughout her life and lost her home several years ago, this made her to turn back to drugs.’

Judge David Hernandez agreed to suspend the sentence to give her the chance to ‘address her addiction’.

She was handed a 16-month sentence, suspended for 18-months after pleading guilty to robbery.

She will also be subject of a six month curfew, and have to undertake a 12-month drug rehabilitation programme and 20 rehabilitation activity requirement days.

Sentencing, the judge told Smith: ‘This is your opportunity to try to put your life back in some sense of order.

‘If you don’t take this opportunity then you will find yourself back her and serving a longer sentence.’
